page.title: 07CUSTOMS OF RIPPINGALE
page.content: In the past many{customs}were observed. Among the most important were a butter market;an annual Temperance Club fete, which was a holiday,with dancing to concertinas in the Manor Barn;and Oak Apple Day when, if one failed to sport an oak leaf,one was stung on the legs by boys with nettles.Empire Day meant singing patriotic songs and saluting the Flag.On Plough Monday farm workers became Mummers in return for refreshment.Foxhunting and bellringing survive as does the May Queen ceremony now held during the July{Feast weekend which is celebrated with fancy dress, brass bands,coconut shies,decorated prams and bikes and various activities in the village hall.The{Harvest Supper is still held,not by the Lord of the Manor,but as a well attended,all ticket affair,in the village hall.
